metadata.case_name: Legal Representatives of the Plaintiff v. The Defendant

facts.text: On June 28, 1962 a flat at New Rajinder Nagar, New Delhi was leased by the plaintiff to the defendant.
Defendant failed to comply with two notices to quit.

Plaintiff filed ejectment application under section 14(1)(e) of the Delhi Rent Control Act, 1958 seeking possession on ground of personal requirement for occupation as residence for himself and family members.

In column 18(a) of ejectment application: 'The premises are required bona fide by the petitioner for occupation as a residence for himself and members of his family and that the petitioner has no other reasonable suitable residential accommodation.'
In column 19: Plaintiff had large family consisting of wife, son, daughter-in-law and 3 minor grand-daughters, with only 2 rooms which were inadequate.
Additional Rent Controller dismissed application on preliminary ground that notices to quit were not valid.
Plaintiff filed appeal; died on August 22, 1968 during pendency.
Appellants 1 to 4 (widow, son, two married daughters) applied to be brought on record as legal representatives.
Tenant opposed, contending son and daughter of deceased daughter also needed to be impleaded.
Rent Control Tribunal by order dated December 13, 1968 allowed those two persons (appellants 5 and 6) to be impleaded.
Tribunal by order dated January 2, 1969 set aside Controller's decision on preliminary issue and remanded for decision on merits.
Tenant's Second Appeal No. 107 of 1969 against remand order dismissed by Delhi High Court on February 20, 1970.
Additional Rent Controller proceeded and on February 14, 1969 held that plaintiff's widow (appellant 1), son (appellant 2), son's wife and three minor daughters required premises bona fide.
Tenant appealed, contending for first time that right to sue did not survive to heirs.
Rent Control Tribunal rejected contention and confirmed eviction order on merits.

In S.A.O. No. 178 of 1970, Delhi High Court held right to sue did not survive to heirs and dismissed ejectment application, leaving open fresh proceedings on heirs' own requirements. Judgment dated May 24, 1971.

legal_issues.text: Whether the cause of action in the Rent-Act application for possession on ground of personal requirement survives to legal representatives of the plaintiff upon his death pending the application.

petitioner_arguments.text: Challenged the Delhi High Court decision dismissing the ejectment application on ground that right to sue did not survive.

respondent_arguments.text: The right to sue did not survive to the heirs of the plaintiff as it was personal requirement.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Section 14(1)(e) of Delhi Rent Control Act, 1958

respondent_arguments.text: Son and daughter of deceased daughter ought to have been impleaded.

court_reasoning.text: The requirement pleaded was personal requirement of the plaintiff for himself and family; such personal cause of action perishes with the plaintiff.
court_reasoning.key_observation: That the members of his family must reside with him is his requirement, not theirs.

court_reasoning.text: If heirs continue, lis assumes complexion beyond original cause of action; would require alteration of pleadings impermissible under Order 6 Rule 17 CPC.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellants' emergence requires determination of their own requirements, not plaintiff's.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguished cases where death after decree, in execution, or of tenant; those rest on different principles.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Plaintiff died before merits decided; no decree accrued.

court_reasoning.text: Maxim actio personalis moritur cum persona applies to personal actions; right to sue means right to same relief asserted by deceased.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Survival under Order 22 Rule 1 CPC depends on whether relief can be enjoyed by representatives.

holdings.text: The right to sue for ejectment on ground of landlord's personal bona fide requirement under section 14(1)(e) does not survive to legal representatives upon death before merits decided.

precedents_cited.relevance: Right to sue means right to bring suit for same relief as deceased plaintiff.
Death after decree for possession; estate entitled to benefit of decree.

precedents_cited.case_name: Amar Nath Bihari v. Jai Dayal Puri
precedents_cited.relevance: Death after Tribunal held requirement for landlord and wife; need consisted of both.

precedents_cited.case_name: Smt. Dhan Devi v. Bakhshi Ram
precedents_cited.relevance: Rights of landlord-decree-holder heritable; in execution/revision after decree.

precedents_cited.case_name: Vas Dev v. S. Sohan Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Executing court cannot go behind decree; requirement satisfied at passing of order.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dr. Muthammad Ibrahim v. Rahiman Khan
precedents_cited.relevance: Turned on peculiar language of Madras House Rent Control Order.
Tenant's death; permission to evict relates to premises condition, enforceable against heirs.

statutes_cited.name: Delhi Rent Control Act, 1958
statutes_cited.relevance: Ground for eviction: premises required bona fide by landlord for occupation as residence for himself or family dependent on him, if owner and no other suitable accommodation.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Survival of right to sue; amendment of pleadings.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Succession Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Demands and rights to prosecute actions survive except for defamation, assault, personal injuries not causing death, or where relief cannot be enjoyed or would be nugatory.

statutes_cited.name: East Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act, 1949
Madhya Bharat Control of Accommodation Act, 1955
U.P. Temporary Control of Rent and Eviction Act, 1947

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court upheld the Delhi High Court's view that the right to sue did not survive to the plaintiff's heirs, as the claim was based on the plaintiff's personal requirement. The appeal was dismissed, affirming dismissal of ejectment application.
outcome.relief_granted: Left open to heirs to bring fresh proceeding on their own requirements.

key_quotes.text: "Such a personal cause of action must perish with the plaintiff."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on non-survival of personal requirement claim.

key_quotes.text: "That the members of his family must reside with him is his requirement, not theirs."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes plaintiff's need from heirs' independent needs.

key_quotes.text: "The right to sue as said succinctly in Saraj Chandra v. Nani Mihan means the right to bring a suit asserting a right to the same relief which the deceased plaintiff asserted."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines survival under Order 22 Rule 1 CPC.
